metadata.titleEn: Time-series anthropogenic heat flux of China land surface
metadata.description: Anthropogenic heat is one of the products of urbanization, which refers to the heat produced by human activities and released into the atmosphere, mainly from various types of energy consumption and biological metabolism. This data set is the surface anthropogenic heat emission flux data of 500m × 500m spatial resolution in China's land surface area from 2000 to 2016 (2000 / 2004 / 2008 / 2012 / 2016). Data sources and processing methods: (1) through the collection of energy consumption data and socio-economic data of provinces and cities in 2000-2016, the annual average AHF of prefecture level cities (prefectures, districts and leagues) is estimated by the inventory method; (2) The AHF estimation model is established based on multi-source remote sensing data, and the grid AHF is obtained; (3) the AHF estimation results of time series are analyzed and tested, and the deviation values are corrected to improve the accuracy of the AHF estimation results. It is of great significance to understand and master the anthropogenic heat emission and its change for understanding the impact of urbanization on climate, environment and society.

background: Anthropogenic heat (AH) generated by human activities has a major impact on urban and regional climate. Intensive human activities produce large amounts of anthropogenic heat (AH) released into the atmosphere. A large amount of AH emissions will increase the urban heat island effect. The increase of temperature will have a series of effects on surface energy conversion and the atmospheric boundary layer, and further affect local air quality. Anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) refers to the amount of anthropogenic heat emission (AHE) generated per unit time and unit area. Many researchers have carried out studies on the estimation of AHF, which generally includes three types of methods: (1) energy balance equation; (2) building energy modeling; (3) the energy-consumption inventory approach. The energy-consumption inventory approach is employed to estimate AHF based on socio-economic data and various types of energy-consumption data, which takes into account the heat released from industry, building, and transportation.
research objective: Accurately estimating anthropogenic heat is of great significance for studies on urban thermal environment and climate change. In this study, a gridded anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) estimation scheme was constructed based on socio-economic data, energy-consumption data, and multi-source remote sensing data using a partition modeling method, which takes into account the regional characteristics of AH emission caused by the differences in regional development levels. It is essential and meaningful to collect the appropriate grid data and comprehensively use the multi-source remote sensing data to construct the AHF estimation model to obtain the gridded AHF data quickly and efficiently, which can better express the spatial difference of AHF inside the municipal administrative divisions.
challenges: The estimation accuracy of the energy balance equation approach is highly dependent on the estimation accuracy of the parameters in the model, including sensible heat, latent heat, and storage heat. Furthermore, an additional issue of the energy balance equation approach is that it relies on flux measurements that are not available for most locations. Since the socio-economic data and energy consumption data are based on administrative division units, the energy-consumption inventory approach can only obtain the mean value of AHF on the spatial scale represented by the statistical data, which cannot show the fine spatial pattern of AHF in the unit. What is more, it is time-consuming and laborious to obtain the complete and detailed socio-economic data and energy-consumption data for large-scale AHF estimations. DMSP/OLS NTL data presented a serious pixel saturation phenomenon in the urban center, which to some extent led to an underestimation of the AHF in the area. However, the characteristics of anthropogenic heat emission may be different due to the differences in regional development levels and climatic conditions. There are some limitations in the same consideration of AHF emission characteristics of all regions in the large-scale AHF estimation.
methods: First, the socio-economic data and energy consumption data are used to estimate the AHF of the municipal (state, district, league) administrative regions in China based on the energy-consumption inventory approach. Next, taking the multi-source remote sensing data as independent variables, such as Suomi-NPP/VIIRS (Suomi national polar-orbiting partnership visible infrared imaging radiometer suite) NTL data which has a larger brightness range and can effectively overcome the pixel saturation phenomenon of DMSP/OLS data and MODIS (moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer) data, and the AHF values obtained by the energy-consumption inventory approach as dependent variables, the gridded AHF estimation models are constructed in eight sub-regions respectively. Then, the performance and accuracy of different estimation models are analyzed and compared, and the optimal set of models are determined as the estimation scheme to achieve the AHF estimation in China. Finally, the refined AHF mapping with a resolution of 500 m was realized in China based on the model.
dataset: Socio-economic data and energy consumption data were derived from statistical yearbooks issued by the national bureau of statistics and local bureau of statistics. Multi-temporal MODIS NDVI (normalized difference vegetation index) (MOD13A1) data were downloaded from the United States Geological Survey (USGS). Suomi-NPP/VIIRS (national polar-orbiting partnership visible infrared imaging radiometer suite) NTL data were available at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
findings: The results show that the spatial distribution of AHF has obvious regional characteristics in China. Compared with the AHF in provinces, the AHF in Shanghai is the highest which reaches 12.56 W·m−2, followed by Tianjin, Beijing, and Jiangsu. The AHF values are 5.92 W·m−2, 3.35 W·m−2, and 3.10 W·m−2, respectively. As can be seen from the mapping results of refined AHF, the high-value AHF aggregation areas are mainly distributed in north China, east China, and south China. The high-value AHF in urban areas is concentrated in 50–200 W·m−2, and maximum AHF in Shenzhen urban center reaches 267 W·m−2. Further, compared with other high resolution AHF products, it can be found that the AHF results in this study have higher spatial heterogeneity, which can better characterize the emission characteristics of AHF in the region. The spatial pattern of the AHF estimation results correspond to the distribution of building density, population, and industry zone. The high-value AHF areas are mainly distributed in airports, railway stations, industry areas, and commercial centers. It can thus be seen that the AHF estimation models constructed by the partition modeling method can well realize the estimation of large-scale AHF and the results can effectively express the detailed spatial distribution of AHF in local areas.

background: Mapping time-series anthropogenic heatflux (AHF) is of great significance for understanding the process of urbanization and its impact on urban environment and climate.
research objective: By collecting energy consumption data and socio-economic statistics, combined with multi-source remotely sensed data, this study mapped the surface AHF in China with a high spatial resolution of 500 m × 500 m from 2000 to 2016 with 4 years of interval through constructing AHF estimation scheme.
challenges: However, due to the large study area, there are still individual administrative areas that lack data, which will bring some uncertainty to the estimation of AHF.
methods: Statistical data including energy consumption data and socioeconomic data from 2000 to 2016 are collected to quantify the AHF in administrative division units. The AHF in prefecture-level city (state, district, league) is quantified by the inventory method according to four categories: industry, transportation, building, and human metabolism. The AHF of prefecture-level city is estimated by the inventory method. On this basis, the grid AHF estimation model is built by establishing the regression relationship between the vegetation adjusted NTL urban index (VANUI) derived from remotely sensed data and the AHF of prefecture-level city to acquire the fine grid AHF with the spatial resolution of 500 m × 500 m. After the preliminary estimation, the deviation value of the time-series AHF results needs to be detected and corrected. Therefore, by comparing the AHF estimation results of adjacent phases, the underestimation areas of each region are extracted. By establishing the fitting function between the normal estimated values of AHF in adjacent phase of each partition as the correction model of the underestimated area, the deviation value of AHF is corrected.
dataset: The data used in the study mainly include statistical data and remote sensing data, as shown in Table 1. Statistical data including energy consumption data and socioeconomic data of provinces and cities are obtained from statistical yearbooks and statistical bulletins issued by the National Bureau of Statistics and local statistical bureaus. Nighttime light data, including DMSP/OLS stable nighttime light data and Suomi-NPP/VIIRS new generation of annual synthetic nighttime light data, are acquired from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The time-series moderate-resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) product data (MOD13A1) come from the United States Geological Survey (USGS), which is a 16-day composite product with a spatial resolution of 500 m.
findings: The main conclusions are: (1) There is a strong correlation between the vegetation adjusted nighttime light urban index (VANUI) and AHF. The highest coefficient of determination (R2) of VANUI and AHF is 0.97 in partition of northwest region (NWR). The average R2 value in partitions is 0.76, which shows that VANUI can well reflect the spatial differentiation characteristics of anthropogenic heat emissions.

Concept Completion.Answer: socio-economic data, energy consumption data, MODIS NDVI data, Suomi-NPP/VIIRS nighttime light data

Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using Suomi-NPP/VIIRS NTL data, which has a larger brightness range and effectively overcomes pixel saturation, combined with MODIS data to construct gridded AHF estimation models in different sub-regions.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using socio-economic and energy consumption data for large-scale AHF estimation?
Example.Answer: A challenge is that socio-economic and energy consumption data are based on administrative division units, leading to mean AHF values that do not capture the fine spatial pattern of AHF within those units.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset used for mapping time-series anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) with high spatial resolution?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used is the Suomi-NPP/VIIRS NTL data from NOAA, combined with MODIS NDVI data from USGS, to achieve a spatial resolution of 500 m × 500 m for AHF mapping from 2000 to 2016.

Definition.Question: What is the 'energy-consumption inventory approach' in the context of estimating anthropogenic heat flux?
Definition.Answer: The energy-consumption inventory approach is a method used to estimate anthropogenic heat flux based on socio-economic data and various types of energy-consumption data. It takes into account the heat released from industry, building, and transportation to calculate the anthropogenic heat emissions.

Definition.Question: How is the 'vegetation adjusted nighttime light urban index (VANUI)' used in estimating anthropogenic heat flux?
Definition.Answer: The vegetation adjusted nighttime light urban index (VANUI) is used in estimating anthropogenic heat flux by establishing a regression relationship between VANUI values derived from remotely sensed data and the anthropogenic heat flux of prefecture-level cities. This aids in acquiring fine grid anthropogenic heat flux with high spatial resolution, reflecting spatial differentiation characteristics of heat emissions.

Comparison.Question: What are the challenges faced in using the energy-consumption inventory approach compared to the energy balance equation approach in estimating anthropogenic heat flux?
Comparison.Answer: The energy-consumption inventory approach is limited by relying on socio-economic data and energy consumption data, which are often based on larger administrative units and can be time-consuming to obtain. It provides mean values that may not capture fine spatial patterns. The energy balance equation approach, on the other hand, depends on the accuracy of model parameters and requires flux measurements that are unavailable in many locations, posing its own challenges.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the mapping results of anthropogenic heat flux using multi-source remote sensing data differ from those using purely statistical data from administrative divisions?
Comparison.Answer: Mapping results using multi-source remote sensing data, such as MODIS NDVI and Suomi-NPP/VIIRS NTL, result in higher spatial heterogeneity and can capture detailed spatial distribution of AHF, reflecting regional development differences more accurately. In contrast, results using purely statistical data are aggregated over larger administrative units, which may overlook local variations in AHF.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of socio-economic data and multi-source remote sensing data improve the accuracy and spatial resolution of anthropogenic heat flux estimations?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of socio-economic data and multi-source remote sensing data allows for the construction of a gridded anthropogenic heat flux estimation model that can capture the spatial differences in heat emissions due to regional development levels. This approach leverages the socio-economic data for energy consumption insights and the spatial richness of remote sensing data to enhance resolution and accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from relying on statistical yearbooks and remote sensing datasets for estimating anthropogenic heat flux across large geographical areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the potential lack of data for individual administrative areas, which can introduce uncertainty in anthropogenic heat flux estimations. Additionally, socio-economic and energy consumption data are often limited to administrative units, restricting the ability to capture fine spatial patterns. Remote sensing datasets may also have limitations like pixel saturation that can affect accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the vegetation adjusted nighttime light urban index (VANUI) be used to infer spatial differentiation of anthropogenic heat emissions?
Interpretation.Answer: The vegetation adjusted nighttime light urban index (VANUI) can be used as it shows a strong correlation with anthropogenic heat flux, with high coefficients of determination in various regions. VANUI effectively reflects spatial differentiation characteristics of heat emissions, enabling the identification of high emission areas and their spatial patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty of accurately estimating anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) using remote sensing data in urban areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The estimation accuracy of AHF using remote sensing data is challenged by issues such as pixel saturation in urban centers, which can lead to underestimation of AHF. Additionally, variations in regional development levels and climatic conditions can affect the characteristics of anthropogenic heat emissions, complicating the estimation process. Furthermore, the energy balance equation approach relies on parameters like sensible heat, latent heat, and storage heat, which may not be accurately estimated due to limited flux measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain detailed socio-economic and energy consumption data for large-scale AHF estimations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Obtaining detailed socio-economic and energy consumption data is time-consuming and labor-intensive, especially for large-scale AHF estimations. The data are typically based on administrative division units, which may not capture the fine spatial patterns of AHF. Furthermore, there are often gaps in data availability for certain administrative areas, leading to uncertainties in AHF estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for correction in the preliminary estimation of time-series anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) results?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The preliminary estimation of time-series AHF results may require correction due to deviations that arise from differences in regional development levels and data gaps in specific administrative areas. These deviations can lead to underestimations of AHF in certain regions. Correction models are needed to adjust the underestimated values by comparing AHF estimation results of adjacent phases and establishing fitting functions for correction.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects could the integration of MODIS NDVI data have on the spatial resolution and detail of AHF mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating MODIS NDVI data, which provides vegetation information, with AHF estimation models could enhance the spatial resolution and detail of AHF mapping. This integration allows for a more nuanced characterization of spatial heterogeneity in AHF emissions, reflecting variations in land cover and usage, thereby improving the ability to express detailed spatial distributions within municipal divisions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind using socio-economic and energy consumption data from statistical yearbooks to estimate anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) in urban areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to accurately estimate anthropogenic heat, which is significant for studying urban thermal environments and climate change. These types of data help in constructing a gridded AHF estimation scheme that considers regional characteristics and allows for efficient and accurate spatial representation of AHF within municipal administrative divisions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the use of the energy-consumption inventory approach in evaluating anthropogenic heat emissions across different administrative units?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The energy-consumption inventory approach is motivated by its ability to estimate AHF based on socio-economic and energy consumption data, considering various sources like industry, buildings, transportation, and human metabolism. This approach provides a mean value of AHF at an administrative level, which is crucial for understanding the overall impact of human activities on urban climates and aiding in the development of policies to mitigate the urban heat island effect.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can multi-source remote sensing data be integrated into the estimation model to improve the accuracy of anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) data across different regions in China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multi-source remote sensing data such as Suomi-NPP/VIIRS and MODIS are used as independent variables in the estimation model. These data sources help to overcome pixel saturation issues and are used in combination with socio-economic and energy consumption data to construct gridded AHF estimation models for various regions. This integration allows for a more accurate spatial representation of AHF by considering the regional characteristics of anthropogenic heat emissions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in correcting the deviation values in the time-series anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) estimation results?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The deviation values of time-series AHF results are detected and corrected by comparing the estimation results of adjacent phases to identify underestimation areas. A fitting function is then established between the normal estimated values of AHF in adjacent phases to serve as a correction model for these areas, which helps to adjust the deviation values and improve accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to handle the challenges posed by incomplete socio-economic and energy consumption data for large-scale anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) estimations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One approach is using the energy-consumption inventory method to estimate AHF within administrative division units. This involves collecting statistical data, including energy consumption and socio-economic data, from yearbooks and bulletins published by national and local bureaus. Additionally, remote sensing data such as nighttime light data and MODIS NDVI are utilized to enhance spatial resolution and fill gaps in statistical data, thereby refining the AHF estimation.

Enablement.Question: What methods or technologies enable the construction of high-resolution anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) estimation models for urban areas in China?
Enablement.Answer: The construction of high-resolution AHF estimation models for urban areas in China is enabled by using a combination of socio-economic data, energy consumption data, and multi-source remote sensing data. Technologies such as the Suomi-NPP/VIIRS NTL data, which offer a larger brightness range and overcome pixel saturation issues, and MODIS data are crucial, alongside the application of partition modeling methods to account for regional development differences.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing data sources facilitate the refinement of spatial resolution in anthropogenic heat flux mapping?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing data sources such as Suomi-NPP/VIIRS nighttime light data and MODIS NDVI products facilitate the refinement of spatial resolution in AHF mapping by providing detailed spatial information that can be integrated with socio-economic and energy consumption data. This integration helps construct gridded AHF estimation models with a fine resolution of 500 m, capturing spatial differences in AHF emissions within administrative divisions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or strategies are necessary for accurately estimating anthropogenic heat flux in regions with limited data availability?
Enablement.Answer: Accurately estimating AHF in regions with limited data availability requires strategies such as developing regression models that establish relationships between remotely sensed indices like the vegetation adjusted NTL urban index (VANUI) and available AHF data. Additionally, detecting and correcting deviation values in time-series data through comparison with adjacent phases and using fitting functions for underestimation areas are necessary conditions to improve estimation accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to achieve fine spatial patterns of anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) using existing energy consumption and socio-economic data?
Expectation.Answer: The energy-consumption inventory approach relies on data based on administrative division units, which can only provide mean values of AHF over these spatial scales. This limitation prevents the method from depicting fine spatial patterns of AHF, as the data do not reflect the detailed spatial differentiation within these units.

Expectation.Question: What potential challenges might arise in the collection and integration of multi-source remote sensing data for AHF estimation models?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in integrating multi-source remote sensing data include addressing issues like pixel saturation in urban centers, as seen in DMSP/OLS data, which can lead to underestimation of AHF. Additionally, variations in regional development levels and climatic conditions imply that uniform data processing methods might not account for differences in anthropogenic heat emissions across regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be uncertainties in estimating AHF for certain administrative areas despite using advanced data collection techniques?
Expectation.Answer: Uncertainties can arise due to individual administrative areas lacking comprehensive data, which affects the reliability of AHF estimations. The large study area can lead to data gaps that introduce uncertainty in the estimation process despite using advanced data collection techniques like multi-source remote sensing and socio-economic data integration.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you believe the inventory method combined with socio-economic and energy consumption data is in estimating anthropogenic heat flux at a large scale?
Judgmental.Answer: The inventory method, when combined with socio-economic and energy consumption data, appears to be effective in estimating anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) at a large scale by providing a mean value of AHF over administrative division units. However, this approach may not capture the fine spatial patterns of AHF due to its reliance on aggregated data. The method's effectiveness could be enhanced by incorporating multi-source remote sensing data to better express spatial differences in AHF within municipal divisions.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using remotely sensed data for estimating anthropogenic heat emissions, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in using remotely sensed data for estimating anthropogenic heat emissions include pixel saturation in urban centers and variations in AHF characteristics due to regional development and climate differences. These issues may lead to underestimations or inaccuracies in AHF measurements. Addressing these challenges could involve selecting data sources with a larger brightness range, like Suomi-NPP/VIIRS, and using partition modeling methods to account for regional differences in AHF emissions.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges associated with collecting comprehensive socio-economic and energy consumption data across such a large geographic area.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the time-consuming and labor-intensive nature of obtaining complete and detailed socio-economic and energy-consumption data for large-scale AHF estimations. Additionally, the data are typically based on administrative division units, which may not provide fine spatial patterns of AHF, leading to potential estimation uncertainties.

Assertion.Question: I can’t make sense of how nighttime light data can be used to refine the spatial resolution of anthropogenic heat flux estimates.
Assertion.Answer: Nighttime light data, specifically from sources like Suomi-NPP/VIIRS, are used to overcome pixel saturation issues present in older datasets and to refine spatial resolution. The data help establish regression relationships between nighttime light indices and AHF, allowing for finer grid AHF estimation models with a spatial resolution of 500 m, enhancing the spatial heterogeneity and detail in the estimation results.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used in estimating anthropogenic heat flux (AHF) and discuss how socio-economic and energy consumption data are integrated with remote sensing data in this process.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for estimating AHF involve gathering socio-economic and energy consumption data from statistical yearbooks issued by national and local bureaus. These data are used to estimate AHF in administrative regions based on the energy-consumption inventory approach. Multi-source remote sensing data, including Suomi-NPP/VIIRS nighttime light data and MODIS NDVI data, are used as independent variables to construct gridded AHF estimation models. This integration allows for a refined spatial resolution of 500 m, capturing the spatial distribution and regional characteristics of AHF.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in the estimation of anthropogenic heat flux using the energy-consumption inventory approach and discuss potential solutions to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in estimating AHF using the energy-consumption inventory approach is the reliance on socio-economic data and energy consumption data, which are often only available at administrative division levels, limiting the spatial resolution. Additionally, detailed data collection is time-consuming and labor-intensive. To address these challenges, the integration of remote sensing data, such as Suomi-NPP/VIIRS and MODIS, helps enhance spatial resolution. Developing models that account for regional development variations and applying correction methods for underestimation can also improve accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources and strategies for expanding or refining datasets used in mapping anthropogenic heat flux across diverse regions in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources for expanding datasets include utilizing more granular socio-economic and energy consumption data from local administrative units, possibly through collaborations with local governments or industries. Strategies for refining datasets could involve enhancing remote sensing data quality and resolution, such as employing newer satellite technologies or combining multiple remote sensing data sources. Additionally, incorporating environmental and climatic data can help refine the understanding of regional differences in AHF emissions.
